title: Kate and William visit mountain-top glacier to see impact of climate change
text:
Prince William and Kate land in Chitral, in the Hindu Khush (Picture: PA)

Prince William and Kate have kick-started their third day in Pakistan with a tour of the country’s glacial regions.

This morning the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge landed in the city of Chitral, in the Hindu Khush, where they were presented with Chitrali hats.

The couple were also given a photo-book remembering Princess Diana’s 1991 visit to the area, which included pictures of her in similar traditional attire.

Kate was heard admiring the embroidery of a coat draped around her shoulders before the couple headed to the northern tip of the Chiatibo Glacier in Broghil National Park.

There, they both witnessed a melting glacier for the first time as they discussed the impact of climate change on Pakistan.

Kate admired the embroidery of the traditional attire (Picture: PA)

This is the third day of their Pakistan tour (Picture: Rebecca English)

They were given hats on their arrival (Picture: EPA)

Kate was overheard admiring the embroidery (Picture: WireImage)

Accompanied by glacier expert Dr Furrukh Bashir, William noted that ‘vulnerable’ communities needed ‘more education, more awareness and political action’ to tackle climate change.

The duke added that ‘the young’ are already becoming engaged in environmentalism, and emphasised the need for a ‘positive conversation’.

He also referenced his geography background, joking: ‘Dr Warren my geography teacher would be well impressed that I’m back at a glacier after all these years.’

Kate then told the expert: ‘I’ve been very impressed by William’s geography.’

Dr Bashir explained that there are more than 5,000 reasonable sized glaciers in the northern mountains of Pakistan, but nearly 70 per cent of them are retreating.

Princess Diana was photographed in a traditional hat during a visit to the Chitral Scouts (Picture: Getty Images)

The couple are in Pakistan until Friday (Picture: Pool / i-Images)

Kate said she had been impressed with her husband’s geography (Picture: Reuters)

Diana made her royal tour in 1991 (Picture: PA)

They will head to local communities as the day goes on (Picture: EPA)

The royal couple will tour the mountains today (Picture: EPA)

He said glaciers require low temperatures at a high altitude and need more snowmelt than snowfall.

Global warming has seen the Chiatibo Glacier retreat by some 10 metres per annum due to higher temperatures melting the ice.

This is causing both the threat of flooding communities down stream, or wiping out their water supply entirely, Dr Bashir said.

He continued: ‘These glaciers are retreating and telling you that climate change is real, global warming is real. A quarter of humanity are dependent on these glaciers.’

During the tour, Kate wore a long taupe-coloured skirt and a darker coloured shirt under a leather vest for the visit, teamed with flat knee-high boots and a beige pashmina.

Kate and William visited a settlement of the Kalash people (Picture: WireImage)

They learned about the community’s heritage (Picture: WireImage)

Their tour of Pakistan will end on October 18 (Picture: WireImage)

The duchess mingled with the locals in traditional dress (Picture: WireImage)

William wore a teal shirt and beige chino trousers as the pair arrived in the mountains by helicopter.

Their outfits were in stark contrast to their glamorous appearance at the historic Pakistan Monument in Islamabad last night, in which they arrived in an auto rickshaw.

Kate wore a glittering emerald dress by Jenny Packham, while William wore a traditional sherwani buttoned coat by Karachi-based designer Naushemian.

During the evening, the duke demonstrated the UK’s support for the Commonwealth country, by telling the reception they could rely on Britain as ‘a key partner and your friend’.

He then ended a speech by quoting Muhammad Ali Jinnah, the lawyer, politician and founder of Pakistan, stating: ‘But we cannot be daunted, nor distracted.’
